channel.title: JMonkeyEngine
channel.description:
I just came across this fantastic Java 3D Game Engine called JMonkey. People use it for all sorts of 3D games, and I am interested in using it too. Apparently, it can be used to make MMORPGs. Does anyone know what I should use to begin making an MMORPG with JMonkey (i.e. assets, server, character movement and saving, etc.)?
I know I'm going a little extreme, but I'm just curious. I don't want to stay with RSPS forever :/
TheCyberMan

item.title: JMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @TheCyberMan TheCyberMan
item.description:
@TheCyberMan wrote:

Thanks for your reply, Graham. The requirements to get started on building an RSPS in Java is beyond my capabilities. Since I can’t find a base source anywhere, I’ll probably develop an MMORPG in Unity 3D.

If I were to develop an MMORPG in Unity 3D I will probably learn C# for better networking.

Does anyone know the pros and cons regarding networking in ‘Unity Javascript’ vs C#? According to Unity, both are equally as fast, and they both use the same .NET platform–Mono.

I am more familiar with Javascript, so please tell me if it would be better to stick with it.

TheCyberMan

Read full topic

item.title: JMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

IlikeArrays:

Who said impossible?

It appears that the OP was edited after Frell said impossible.

Also, imho JME isn’t amazing. The API isn’t very stable, as Taharok hinted at, and I personally don’t like some of the design. You don’t have a huge amount of choice if you’re going to use Java. There are some fairly nice C++ engines though - I’m doing a project in Ogre3D at the moment - so you might want to consider checking some of those out.

As for making a simple MMORPG, there are obviously two main components: the client and the server. Both can be kept fairly simple at first: just make the server keep track of all the players and broadcast updates to everyone (e.g. a player logged in, a player moved, etc). Eventually you’ll want to extend it so the server only broadcasts updates about players that are near to the player receiving the updates, this involves keeping a local list of players within view of each client. The simple way to do this is a loop within a loop, check the updating sequence in some winterlove-based server for an example.

The client needs to also keep track of players it knows about, and since you are using JME actually getting the models displayed will be quite easy as you just need to add a node to the scene graph. You’ll also eventually need to interpolate movement, since you can’t send movement updates in real time due to bandwidth constraints, but the movement still needs to appear smooth on the client. You can do that with some simple maths.

Obviously you’d need to also devise a protocol for communication, but that is also quite easy. Since you seem to be somewhat familiar with private servers, you could take an approach similar to Jagex or maybe you want to be more exotic. You just need to define a format in general for the packets (e.g. having a header consisting of an opcode byte and length word, followed by the packet data) as well as the formats in individual packets (e.g. adding a new player might have fields for the player id, name, x/y/z coords and rotation).

I wouldn’t worry so much about loading/saving players at first, that’s a somewhat boring detail when you are trying to get the more visual things working and if you’re capable of the above, a bit of file I/O or database stuff won’t be too taxing :p.

Read full topic

item.title: JMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I’m only partially familiar with JME. It seems to be a pretty well constructed library, but like HcoJustin said, it’s really bloated and lost all hopes for easy portability. If I didn’t have the option to make my own game engine and had to choose an existing one, I’d probably choose Xith3D over JME, because Xith has retained its portability over the years. Xith is also modeled after Java3D, but more lightweight since it uses LWJGL rather than internal dependencies. I think Xith can support using LWJGL or Java3D for its backend, as well. This adds additional scalability for those whom have Java3D installed, and for the game maker that wishes to utilize DirectX through Java3D, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: JMonkeyEngine
item.dc:creator: @TheCyberMan TheCyberMan
item.description:
@TheCyberMan wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:3, topic:414975”][quote author=TheCyberMan link=topic=516935.msg3754089#msg3754089 date=1316288936]
Also, is there a way to use the RSPS server with a different client/engine? I would REALLY like that.
[/quote]

If you don’t mind rewriting the entire client then go for it!

On a side note, JME2 was great, JME3 ruined it by bringing all the aspects of game development together. (Physics, asset system, etc.) It is almost to the point of being a drag and drop game creator now.[/quote]Lol, I don’t know why I asked that. It’s plain obvious

Do you have any guidance for creating a base login protocol, movement, and client with JMonkey?

item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

TheCyberMan:

Also, is there a way to use the RSPS server with a different client/engine? I would REALLY like that.

If you don’t mind rewriting the entire client then go for it!

On a side note, JME2 was great, JME3 ruined it by bringing all the aspects of game development together. (Physics, asset system, etc.) It is almost to the point of being a drag and drop game creator now.
